This video sparked multiple epiphanies for me. The way quantum mechanics are normally explained is just confusing. Do some scientists actually believe a "wave function" is a physical property of particles? Just hearing this alternate theory reminded me that a lot of these math formulas and theories are not necessarily the ground truth. They're just mathematical models based on incomplete (or incompletable) observations. The wave function isn't some sort of magical force of nature that can tell when it's being observed, it's a mathematical formula that abstracts out things we don't know in order to make an estimation. Collapsing the wave function for a particle just means we know the state of the particle and don't have to estimate anymore.

In the same vein, quantum entanglement sounds like sci fi mumbo jumbo that would enable faster-than light communication or travel. Quantum entanglement isn't an actual link between two particles, it's just two particles that happen to sync up and behave in the same manner until you alter one, and the particles are manufactured by just randomly mashing them together until they happen to sync up. It's like if you flipped enough coins in a vacuum, eventually you would find 2 coins that were flipped with the same force, so their rotation syncs up perfectly.

I don't know if I'm missing some key concepts that convolutes everything, but I think quantum mechanics in general are sensationalized to the point that it causes a lot of misconceptions.

When we measure things we are recording data at a particular point in time. Measuring the distance, velocity, oscillation, rotation of a "thing" requires at least two points of data. More points of data gives us more information (kind of like two photos vs a video). For things in motion, measurement is complicated by the speed and size of the thing being measured.

Consider a tube of water. If you record the position of a single molecule of water at the starting end of a water hose, then its location at another position, say, the end of the hose, and divide by time, you might conclude its velocity. But you would only know its velocity "from" point A to point B. And you would have to make assumptions about its velocity (and position) at any points in between.

So what if the water hose started at a valve on the front of a building, but ran underneath the building and you found the other end coming out on the other side of the building? You would not know the length of the hose (distance) from point A to point B.

if you knew the velocity of the water coming out of the valve was 50 ft per minute, and you placed a blue pellet (neutral bouyancy lets say) in the stream at the valve, and it came out on the other side of the building exactly 1 minute later, you might conclude that the length of the hose jnder the building was 50 ft. Especially if you were able to repeat this experiment multiple times with the same result. Likewise, if the pellet appeared consistently 2 minutes later, then you could conclude that the hose was 100 ft long.

But what if the pellet appeared on the other end at seemingly random time intervals? The water is still flowing. The velocity of the water at the entry point and exit point is still 50 ft per min. Nothing has changed. But the pellet appears at random times. What would you conclude?

What if you repeated this 10 times and the exit times were 1 min, 5 mins, 2.3 min, 3.14 mins, and so on? What you are missing is the Diameter of the hose under the building. Maybe it changes to a tank, not a hose. And then back to a hose on the other side. So the pellet moves through the hose at a somewhat constant rate. But once it enters the tank, it doesn't follow a set path of flow. It will eventually make it to the other side and exit the hose for you to see and mark its time. But the times will be seemingly random.

Even so, if you repeated this experiment thousands of times, and plotted the times, you would eventually observe a pattern. The Range of times would be confined to, say, 1 minute to 10 minutes. But a vast majority of the times would fall within a smaller range.

Additionally, from the patterns you detect, you could make conclusions about the Size of the tank. The larger the tank, the greater the range of exit times. The lesser the range, the smaller the tank.

So here is a question: If the silicone droplet experiment is a good model of the pilot wavey model of quantum mechanics, what does it say about the underlying nature of “particles” in pilot wave theory?

It says that _the droplets are not particles either_. They are just smaller waves.

Suppose an experiment sends an electron through an exceptionally tiny hole. A common intuition is that the electron then becomes a “particle” that sails in a straight path. Nothing is farther from the truth! The electron instead radiates outwards as a hemispherical wave, with its probability of “landing” being equal in all directions. It becomes more wave-like, not less.

The silicone drop and pilot-wave models of quantum mechanics suffer from the same subtle problem. Both superpose two versions of a particle’s quantum wave function onto the same space at one moment in time.

In the entirely classical silicone droplets model, the droplet-wave and guiding-wave can genuinely exist simultaneously. In quantum mechanics, there can only ever be one wave at one time… ever.

This quantum insistence every entity having only one wave at any one moment in time is why the silicone droplet model, while instructive, is also profoundly deceptive. It creates an illusion of a separate particle by superposing the initial large wave with a much smaller post-observation “particle” wave. The result is an illusion that the two waves can coexist in time. They cannot. Indeed, through entropy, each waveform’s insistent isolation appears deeply linked to the nature of time itself.


Finally, in fairness, pilot-wave theories are by no means the only quantum interpretations that engage in superposing quantum waves that experimentally can exist only at separate points in classical time. Quantum field theory is the gold star standard for the mathematically accurate prediction of quantum phenomena. Its success relies on superpositions of point-like particle states that are just as experimentally impossible and even more redundant than those of pilot-wave theory. There is a cost, however. Much of quantum field theory is devoted to issues such as vacuum energy, charge hiding, asymptotic freedom, and renormalization that are directly related to the impact of superposing wave functions that can only exist sequentially in physical reality.

The particle and the disturbance in the medium are quite distinct things. In the pilot wave theory, the pilot waves are not any disturbance created by the particle, rather it is part of the particle itself, only we choose to give it a different name. So, while in the droplet two-slit expt, the droplet going through a particular slit, interacts with the disturbance passing through both the slits, in the pilot wave theory, the "particle" going through a particular slit, interacts with its own "pilot wave". In other words, the particle going through one slit, interacts with a part of itself which went through the other slit. But this is what we say in the standard interpretation of quantum mechanics, that particle passes through both the slits, and interferes with itself. So, calling one part of the particle "particle" and another part of the same particle "pilot wave", is artificial, and does not provide any advantage.

Don't assume that because this system reproduces SOME results of quantum experiments that it will reproduce all of them. I'm a big fan of the hidden variables theory (out of which the wavefunctions in QM are built up). What I like so much is that there is a mechanism that mimics the probability interpretation. How can an event based on irreducible chance take place?  How does a particle "know" when it's going to decay, for example? You can, of course, say that the irreducible chances determine when a particle decays, but what does that mean? How does a particle "feel" when it's going to decay?  Chance is a human made concept, involving our lack of knowledge, which is then applied to, say a dice, and in this picture if you roll a perfect dice, the chances are one sixth of each number on the dice in the limit of an infinite amount of rolls of the dice. Now how can you objectivize this human concept and apply it to the interpretation of QM, while hidden variables are much more objective and offer a neat explanation of the so-called inherently, irreducible chance interpretation of the Copenhagen interpretation? For the Brown-particle in a fluid, the movements are not inherently chance based. There is even an uncertainty relation developed for the Brown-particle. But we know that the erratic behavior of the Brown-particle is caused by the actions of enormous amounts of the molecules in the fluid, which can be compared to hidden variables.

'Pilot wave' is a misnomer. Why use a 'wave'? The 'wave' is already an interpretation of a process that is going on. It is a picture of a process, so to speak, and that picture has certain stylistic biases and inadequacies. We don’t have to go that route. The Copenhagen school goes the particle-wave duality route because it wants to convince in a certain interpretation, certain drawing style which it calls the reality, so to speak, and thus confuses the matter to the extent that it calls an alternative view — the 'pilot wave'. That is, it uses the language of its own terminology to describe an alternative view. Then, it finds 'problems in it'.
In truth, it only repeats own problem. The Copenhagen school view is popularised, reiterated in books and articles like an undeniable truth. It uses certain simplistic language for almost a century now. Copenhagen-school-world-terminology is so confusingly re-iterated now that we think we can’t understand 'all the advances' because we are not clever enough to understand incomprehensible new permutations of same words. But the truth is, if we use the terminology of the Copenhagen school, we use inadequate language.
Better way would be to talk about processes, talk about concepts, and then slowly find new idioms and build better language to describe them.

I'll put it in terms of "Occam's Razor" - when he said, "the simpler explanation is more likely to be correct" the word "simple" doesn't mean "easily understood" it means "the one that requires the fewest unverified pre-requisites." For instance, before someone can debate wither some particular crop circle was made by aliens, there must first 1) be aliens that 2) have space travel abilities and 3) have used them to visit earth 4) otherwise undetected 5) and like making crop circles. On the other hand, for a crop circle to have been made by a person there must first be 1) people who like playing pranks 2) with access to string 3) able to move around in a field in the middle of nowhere without being notice, etc.

The pilot wave theory requires that pilot waves exist, which is unverified. I'm not aware of any comparable prerequisites that the Copenhagen interpretation is built on.

But more importantly, just because one theory is more concrete and the other is more abstract doesn't make the abstract one inferior. The Copenhagen interpretation is more mentally challenging - but that is not a factor in its favor or against it. The laws of nature don't care whether we can easily make sense of them or not.

Pilot wave theory is interesting, but at least as described here it doesn't really seem consistent with quantum entanglement, the observation that although quantum properties of individual particles are random, in aggregate they obey the conservation laws.

Furthermore, experiments such as the Bell-Aspect experiment and others strongly suggest that the random properties of individual particles really aren't determined until they are measured.

So if there is a pilot wave, then to satisfy the conservation laws (entanglement) that wave would have to transfer properties from one particle to another at faster-than-light speed, which violates the principles of locality (i.e. effects arise from local causes) and causality (i.e. effects don't precede causes in any observer's reference frame).

Furthermore, if the pilot wave can transfer properties from one particle to another, then how does the pilot wave avoid being able to have those properties? By analogy, UPS couldn't deliver packages unless it could (at least temporarily) have them. But if the pilot wave can have those properties, then the properties wouldn't appear to be conserved from looking at the particles.

I don't think the Copenhagen Interpretation works either. Gell-Mann famously called it "quantum flapdoodle".

Everett's Interpretation (now called "Many Worlds") seems to work. It nicely explains quantum entanglement without faster-than-light information, and it doesn't require the mystical and un-modelable wave function collapse like the Copenhagen Interpretation does.

Pilot wave, or de Broglie's original Theory of the Double Solution from which PW descended, is a no-go for me. I was fascinated with this idea long ago, in grad school. But it didn't survive.

For one, it does a poor job dealing with multiple identical particles. Two electrons need two pilot waves. Just what is it that's doing the waving? In the demo with the dancing drops, it's the surface of the water or oil, a single "universal" shared entity filling space, with one wavefunction - height above the average surface. Attempts to make Pilot Wave quantum mechanics work like that fail. It's inherent in the math of QM that each particle needs its own wave.

Then there's metaphysical garbage to be collected. Suppose an electron goes flying along then whack! Right into a piece of metal. There's be a circular pilot wave escorting it along until the electron stops - does the pilot wave suddenly stop? All at once? Does the part of it near the electron suddenly stop along with the electron while the outer parts continue? Is there an outward ring of sudden-slowing of the PW, expanding at the speed of light? Are there 10^hundreds of 'empty' pilot waves fluttering through every point of space from all the electrons which suddenly changed motion or were cancelled out of existence by positrons?

Real QM doesn't have an answer to such questions because we just throw away the wavefunction, and write a new one for the electron in its new home. This is unsatisfying to Human minds, but it's what works. Reality is weird.

Finally, pilot wave theory is deterministics, and "realistic" in the sense of EPR paradoxes and Bell Theorem. PW will obey Bell's inequalities. Reality, as measured by experiments since the 1990s, does not. Entanglement is real, and is described by Hilbert space mathematics of the sort that lets you fly past Bell's limitations. PW just can't do that.

So goodbye Pilot Wave, and I won't waste time on meaningless fluff like Many Worlds. Interpretations based on subtleties of statistics don't generalize or explain Delayed Choice experiments, and other interpretations... I could write a book. Copenhagen is empty, philosophically unsatisfying, but truly nothing better has come along. Copenhagen works for the practical everyday physicist or electronics engineer.

For the first time, I think I disagree with your point of view and explanation. I don't thing that there's any fundamental contradiction between the Copenhagen Interpretation and the Pilot Wave Visualisation. As I understand it, the Copenhagen Interpretation doesn't aim to describe the nature of the electron itself —or any other particle—, it only aims to describe its movement and behaviour. In the same sense that de classical equation we use to describe an object, for example, in free fall —s(t) = s0 + v0t + (gt^2)/2— doesn't intent to say anything about the nature of the object falling, it just tells us about its movement. In this sense, taking the example of the double slit, I think it's incorrect to say that, according to the Copenhagen Interpretation, the electron "is" a superposition of two states: the electron passing by Slit 1 and the electron passing by Slit 2. Instead, what the Copenhagen Interpretation says is that the best description, the most knowledge, we can have of the movement of the electron, not of the electron itself, is that it has a certain probability of passing by each slit and landing at certain spots in the screen. Extending this idea to the famous cases of setting setting detectors on the slits to find out by which one it passes through —or what happens to the probability wave after it hits the screen— is not different in essence from a simple conditional probability problem, isn't it? Once with limit the probability outcomes with a condition —knowing where the electron has been— the final probably changes. By detecting the electron we change out knowledge of the system and the system itself. Our knowledge/description/wave-function changes, because now we know where the electron is. While the system/experiment changes, because to detect the electron we had to interact with it, thus altering its movement, hence it's not anymore a double slit experiment. But that again doesn't say anything about the nature of the electron, only about our description about its movement. What collapses with the wave function is not the electron itself, but our knowledge. So, in my view, the Pilot Wave Visualisation does not contradict the Copenhagen Interpretation, on the contrary, adds to it something it lacks: valuable insight on what the electron may actually be.

Hi Veritasium, I'm a fan of your videos and as a scientist, I'm always impressed with how you're able to bring complex concepts to a lay audience. I'd never seen the pilot waves before, and not only would this have inspired me as a kid, it absolutely set me on fire right now seeing macroscopic objects recover some of the properties of subatomic particles.

However, I was honestly upset by your final statements turning these phenomena into an "alternative theory" to standard quantum mechanics. Attempts to create non-random interpretations of quantum mechanics relying on "hidden variables" were proven impossible in the 1960s by Bell's Theorem (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hidden_variable_theory, https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bell%27s_theorem).

Pointy-headed science researchers have an unfortunate tendency to get bent out of shape whenever an elegant popular explanation of gets some detail wrong. I really try not to do that, because that's really how science works: building more and more detailed models of how the world functions. And for that to work, you have to start with some basic model, and there are going to be details missing.

That's not what's in the end of this video. I would have been happy with a closing statement saying "This IS how quantum mechanics works." Or, better, "This is pretty much how quantum mechanics works! There are some things missing, though. If you want more details, grab a textbook or a physics professor!" Instead, it was strongly implied that the unsettling, random aspects of quantum mechanics could be removed, when in fact they have withstood the test of time for more than eighty years despite the very best efforts of some of the finest minds science has ever known to discredit them (including most famously Einstein and Max Planck), and in fact have even gained theoretical underpinning (Bell's Theorem), which itself is settled, fifty-year-old science.

Please, as a science educator, don't lend credibility to "alternative theories." At the best, people inspired to study physics by this video will have a much harder time with already very difficult subjects. At worst, it will lead people to disregard those grumpy old researchers and into the rabbit hole of dangerous pseudosciences like homeopathy and anti-vaxxing. Keep up the good work.

From the Everettian multiverse, or unitary quantum mechanics a.k.a MWI, standpoint, the pilot wave is just the cumulative effect of all the other versions of particle interacting with it. The problem with the Pilot Wave view is that it singles out one of those versions as the only real one and demotes all the others to be constituents of the background pilot wave. In this, it is somewhat reminiscent to me of the Tyco Brahe's hybrid model of the solar system where all planets, except Earth, revolved around the sun while the Earth was somehow singled out and the sun and its orbiting planets revolving around it. Such hybrids are generally bad explanations their special singling out is ultimately a form of bias. This bias creates defects in their explanatory power. In the case of the pilot wave, it confines it to working on a specific basis all the time, has trouble incorporating spin, and is forced to accommodate for non-local effects. Even worse, the way the 'wave' interacts is very specific. It always interacts "as if" it was made by other versions of that particle subject to its particular setup. For example, if you put a barrier on one of the paths in the interference experiment, it effects the outcome only if the barrier is opaque to the passage of the particle. If it is transparent, it doesn't effect it at all. A general non-local spread out wave piloting  shouldn't be so specific and idiosyncratic in how it acts.This shows that the addition of  "as if" in the sentence above is superfluous. Doesn't add anything to the actual explanation. If you get rid of it, you get MWI back again with all its explanatory power.

De Broglie-Bohm (the largest pilot wave interpretation in quantum mechanics) has rightly been sidelined in mainstream physics. Its nonlocality may make it compatible with Bell's theorem, but it also means you no longer have access to a lot of the most powerful machinery of field theories because you can no longer define a Lagrangian density which, in turn, means you lose any access to the formalism or tools we have to do quantum field theory and so are relegated to the non-relativistic regime.

Copenhagen is also pretty much universally regarded as incorrect but a necessary evil. Objective collapse theories (such as copenhagen) suffer a lot because they now require two distinct forms of time evolution (unitary evolution and non-unitary collapse) and copenhagen also adds the problem that there's no non-arbitrary way of deciding which measurements cause collapse. On the other hand, copenhagen has the major advantage of it being very obvious and relatively easy to get numbers out of it and so, despite most physicists agreeing that copenhagen isn't what's really going on, but it is the one we use to calculate.

Ultimately, all true interpretations produce the same measurements and so most of time, we tend not to worry too much about interpretations any more and so tend not to have particularly strong opinions but most people I know tend to subscribe to some-sort of many worlds/many minds interpretation or one where collapse is just what entanglement looks like from the inside.

Incredibly educational video. I researched this viewpoint and understanding the measurement problem theoretically during my undergraduate years; I don't consider any of them to be (completely) true anymore, but it enlightened me on what the problem was and the stigma associated with it. Quantum physicists look at the measurement problem, i.e. how we see particles during measurements when we treat them like abstract collections of states beforehand, like the big philosophical elephant in the room. If you question it, many professors - some in the department I was in last year - say boldly that only the Copenhagen school is the only correct one. The Copenhagen viewpoint and this competing "pilot-wave" theory as it's called, that was originally by de Broglie and precisely formulated by David Bohm and Basil Hiley a few decades later, have been fighting for a while now. In fact, they and even the multiple universes or many worlds interpretations are nothing but philosophies attached to the same theory of physics.

In reality, quantum mechanics says nothing about "wave-function collapse" or multiple universes; it doesn't even say electrons can be in two places at once. Instead, as a mathematicians, we view quantum mechanics as an algorithm, a mathematical structure, for generating probability distributions for the possible behaviors a physical system can undertake in time. It is well-known that some purely mathematically equivalent reformulations exist, and of course we have these physical reformulations which are mathematically extremely similar but where the symbols have different meanings, still giving the same observational results (not all the time, but most aim to do this, and scores of physicists have debated if certain interpretations really do satisfy this criterion of being observationally indistinguishable from Copenhagen models). But nobody really knows how an electron gets from one point to another, and after using quantum mechanics formally for a century, that's an astounding fact.

Sean Carroll on his blog called a survey where physicists mainly disagreed on their interpretations "the most embarrassing graph in modern physics." So, it is important to distinguish several things: quantum mechanics works well without interpretations, including Copenhagen views, yet those interpretations could be right or wrong and influence research in, say, quantum gravity, and so they are just as important. We need more people like this to ask these deep questions so more research is undertaken.

@5:20 "I think it at least suggests that this is possible." In my opinion, this is the key point. The reason why the Copenhagen interpretation exists is rooted in the old apparent contradiction that light is both a wave (Maxwell and many others) and that is made of particles (Einstein and the photoelectric effect). The consensus at the time was that, since a physical object cannot be both a wave and a particle simultaneously, there has to be a mechanism somewhere that changes the nature of the object at some point in time. And thus was born the infamous collapse of the wave function, and the unreasonable importance of the observer/measurement.

What this line of research in hydrodynamics demonstrates is not a mirror image of the quantum world, and all researchers in that field are perfectly aware of that fact and very prudent about drawing conclusions by simple analogy. But this unequivocally demonstrates that a real physical object can definitely be a wave and a particle, both at the same time. There just doesn't need to be a contradiction here. As Derek says, it becomes a possibility, and when considering QM, one has then to wonder if invoking a collapse that suddenly transforms a delocalized cloud of probabilities into a very localized impact on a detector is actually necessary at all, or even reasonable.

The video shows a particle going through a specific slit while still generating an interference pattern. This stands in sharp disagreement with quantum behavior of particles, according to which the interference pattern disappears whenever you know through which slit the particle went. In addition to that, such a simplistic pilot wave model would have a very hard time accounting for entanglement. Unfortunately, no convincing complete theory of pilot waves has ever been formulated, and none of these theories seem to resolve all mysteries associated with QM without generating other non-trivial mysteries.

I've always felt a little skeptical of the Copenhagen interpretation and hoping for a more deterministic explanation like this to be discovered - but there's one often glossed over aspect of the double slit experiments in which I don't think pilot waves can replicate the behavior of quantum particles like electrons -- when experimenters set up a device that can record through which slit each electron travels when fired one at a time, the electrons instantly switch to behaving as particles, and the interference pattern disappears. The analog with pilot waves would be if, when you switch on the camera to observe through which slit the oil bead is traveling, the standing waves instantly disappear, and the bead then travels along the surface in a straight line. When you switch the camera back off, the waves reappear, and the beads begin to interfere with one another again, even though fired one at a time. The electrons behave as though they know when they are being observed, and then act as particles, and instead act as waves when they are not observed. This is why the Copenhagen interpretation concludes that an individual electron must exist in all its possible positions at once, until the instant it is observed -- whether it's first observed at the slits or on the wall when it hits determines its subsequent behavior.

One argument against the pilot-wave interpretation (also called Bohmian mechanics, or De Broglie-Bohm theory) is that it seems considerably harder to make the theory consistent with relativity theory. Combining the standard Copenhagen interpretation with relativity theory gives standard quantum field theory. However the pilot-wave interpretation is much harder to reconcile with relativity theory, and I'm not sure that a satisfactory relativistic theory/interpretation has been developed yet.
The most prominent problem is the following: the pilot-wave theory is non-local. Each particle is 'guided' by a pilot-wave. But this pilot-wave depends simultaneously on all the particles in the universe. This means that if we have an electron, its velocity is dependent instantaneously on the position of every other electron in the entire universe, no matter how far away they are to our electron. This is what is means for the theory to be non-local, and it seems to violate the 'speed limit' enforced by relativity theory.

As an alternative to standard quantum mechanics, however, it boggles me that it is not even as far as mentioned in undergraduate physics courses. Clearly as a theory of quantum mechanics it makes the exact same predictions as the Copenhagen picture, yet provides a deterministic theory. The Copenhagen interpretation of QM doesn't state that the universe "isn't deterministic". In fact, the Schrödinger equation, which governs the time evolution of the state function, is fully deterministic. The only thing that is non-deterministic is the result of a measurement of some particular "property" of the object, but this is due to the fact that we must think of every measurement as a collision. Furthermore, the principle of uncertainty is simply a result of whether or not two operators corresponding to a particular measurable commute. Since, in the example of position "x" and momentum "p", [x, p] != 0, it is impossible and furthermore makes no sense to discuss knowledge of both the position and momentum of the quantum mechanical system. I see how de Broglie- Bohm mechanics is particularly comforting, and why it must appeal to so many, but the knowledge that arose from the Copenhagen interpretation of QM has been far more useful and successful. After all, "...the 'paradox' is only a conflict between reality and your feeling of what reality 'ought to be.'" - Richard Feynman

I think that in many ways this is very easily compatible with Bohr's thoughts on how the experiments they knew about at the time probably couldn't be properly explained within the boundaries of the experiments themselves. The biggest "disagreement" between the Einstein's and Bohr's views at least were that quantum mechanics could be measured indirectly in the way we measure normal physics, after all. That's what they focus on for the most part, the idea that the measuring interferes with the experiment. If you read some of the papers they wrote on how to measure positions and so on it looks more like Bohr was just skeptical about the way the results were explained as general, with a fairly reasonable view that if you somehow determined the position of an electron to a single point, then it already would behave like a particle - more than that they were imagining that electromagnetic waves were both waves and particles specifically at the same time, just to mess with the equations, or something like that. Bohr turns pretty sarcastic at times when it comes to the mathematical proof, but generally just condones the research effort. Very soft criticism all round, really. Most of the ire comes from positivists who simply mock critics who subscribe to a more off-handed approach ala Kuhn: we might find something else later that supplants all the experimental data output and all the theories explicitly built on it, so don't get too arrogant, etc.

So I'm not sure that the Copenhagen interpretation, at least from what Bohr suggested, is incompatible with the pilot wave thing. Really, the whole quantum field idea and the pilot wave, that both insist on that what we're measuring really is an energy bump that resonates in everything around it (with mechanics taking place in between that we simply can't map properly) seems very compatible with the ideas Bohr had at the time on what exactly "quantum mechanics", as seen from the experiments known then (that really has been pretty much the same until fairly recently) really was.

Imagine that electrons who passed a double-slit forms the droplets in the bath. These will go to an another double-slit. With this set-up you can't predict where the droplets will be. Until they will hit the screen. Then the wave function of the droplets will collapse.

The difference between the YT-video is that we won't know where the droplets will start and pass the double-slit. We only know the possibilities where the electrons could be and where the droplets form and start to go through the second double-slit. It's like the classic double-slit-experiment. You do not know where the electrons will start.

Would that change the probability where the droplets will hit the screen? No. Because the effect of collapsing wave function of the oil droplets are marginal. The droplets have a huge energy according to E=mc^2. The wavelength of the droplet (seen as one particle) is ridiculously small. Smaller than the plank-length. So the probality that the droplet will be at a new place after observing it is so small that we will never observe it.

And that's the only difference between the original double-slit-experiment and the oil bath. When the energy is big enough, the wave function can collapse with no effect of the probalities of your double-slit-experiment.

My theoretical idea concerning the dual slit experiment:

1. Charged particles have their associated magnetic fields with them.
2. Protons and electrons are charged particles and have their associated magnetic fields with them.
3. Photons also have both an electrical and magnetic components to them.
4. Whenever a proton, electron, or photon is shot out of a gun, it's respective magnetic field interacts with the magnetic fields of the electrons in the atoms and molecules of the gun itself, the medium the projectile is traveling thought (ie: air), and/or from around the slits themselves.
5. Via QED (quantum electrodynamics), newly generated photons might occur.
6. The projectile goes on it's own way and the newly generated photons go on their own way. It gives the illusion of a wave particle duality, but it is not that way in actual reality.
7. As far as detectors are concerned, they probably have an energy field that is one way when on and a different way when off. The interaction of this energy field (or the lack thereof) with whatever is passing through it, gives the indication that is observed.

c. How exactly does an observer in physical reality actually observe these probability waves and condense them down into one single physical reality?
d. Who and/or what observed the first observer?
e. What exactly happens when two or more observers observe different probability waves? Which one takes precedent in physical reality?

John Bell himself was a fan of pilot wave theories as this 1986 quote demonstrates "While the founding fathers agonized over the question 'particle' or 'wave', de Broglie in 1925 proposed the obvious answer 'particle' and 'wave'. Is it not clear from the smallness of the scintillation on the screen that we have to do with a particle? And is it not clear, from the diffraction and interference patterns, that the motion of the particle is directed by a wave? De Broglie showed in detail how the motion of a particle, passing through just one of two holes in screen, could be influenced by waves propagating through both holes. And so influenced that the particle does not go where the waves cancel out, but is attracted to where they cooperate. This idea seems to me so natural and simple, to resolve the wave-particle dilemma in such a clear and ordinary way, that it is a great mystery to me that it was so generally ignored."
